info.title: IT Wallet API - EAA Issuance Flow
info.description: API for the Italian EUDI Wallet implementation profile (version: '0.6.0') https://italia.github.io/eudi-wallet-it-docs/v0.6.0/en/

post.summary: Starts authorization flow for the Wallet
post.description:
1. Wallet Instance have previously:
    • obtained EAA Provider federation metadata (Entity Configuration) that discloses the URL endpoints, public keys, algorithms supported, credential types supported, and any other parameter required for interoperability needs;
    • created a PKCE code verifier and its challenge (SHA256) for the Pushed Authorization Request (PAR Request) to send to this endpoint;
    • created a PAR Request for starting an authorzation flow to obtain an access token that authorize to access to the /credential endpoint for requesting a single specific tipology of EAA Credential (i.e. DisabilityCard).
  2. Wallet Instance sends a PAR Request to this endpoint
  3. Authorization Server validates PAR Request received;
  4. Authorization Server extracts the identifier of the Wallet Instance (client_id), the Wallet Instance side application session (state), the WTE and its proof of possession (WTE-PoP), validates and storing them in the local database along with the PAR Request using the state as key;
  5. Authorization Server extracts from the WTE of the Wallet Provider's identifier that issued the Wallet Instance (claim iss) and uses it to verify the presence in the local database of a valid trust chain related to the Wallet Provider (in case of absence it starts a federation flow that provides for building the Wallet Provider's trust chain and storing it in the local database by associating it with the PAR Request);
  6. Authorization Server validates the signature of the WTE using the Wallet Provider's federation public key contained in the Wallet Provider's Entity Configuration retrieved from its trust chain; the identifier of this public key (specified into the claim kid) must match exactly the claim kid specified in the WTE header;
  7. Authorization Server verifies that the Wallet Instance is the rightful owner of the submitted WTE by going to validate the signature of the WTE-PoP and checking if the public key of the Wallet Instance to which the WTE is bound (contained into the WTE claim cnf) is the same public key referenced by the claim kid of the WTE-DPoP header;
  8. Authorization Server extracts the JWT request object from the PAR Request (claim request) and verifies its signature using the public key of the Wallet Instance to which the WTE is bound (contained into the WTE claim cnf);
  9. Authorization Server generates a time-limited disposable request uri that identifies the PAR Request within the Authorization Server (e.g., SHA1 hash of the PAR Request) and creates a PAR Response that encapsulates that URI (claim request_uri) and its validity interval (claim request_uri_expires_in);
  10. Authorization Server stores the identifier of the Wallet Provider, request_uri, request_uri_expires_in and PAR Response in local database by associating them with the previously saved PAR Request
  11. Authorization Server sends PAR Request to the Client.

get.summary: Issuing an authorization code to the Wallet Instance
get.description:
1. Wallet Instance opens its web view and sends an Authorization Request, to this endpoint that presents in query string the Wallet Instance identifier (client_id), the request_uri returned by the PAR Response;
  2. Authorization Server validates and stores in local database the Authorization Request, associating it with the PAR Request saved previously and identified through the client_id and the request_uri parameters specified in the request;
  3. Authorization Server redirects the Wallet Instance to the login service of the Relying Party (RP). The redirect set a session cookie (called state) that contains the unique application session identifier at the Wallet Instance side (previously sent in the PAR Request). The login service of RP will then authenticate the Wallet Instance user by verifying the eID Credential that is required as input.

parameters.name: client_id
parameters.description: It MUST be set to the same value in the PAR Request (in URL-encoded format)

parameters.name: request_uri
parameters.description: It MUST be set to the same value as obtained by PAR Response (in URL-encoded format)

parameters.name: code
parameters.description: It is the value obtained in response of /callback service of RP Wallet

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: Contains the unique application session identifier at the Wallet Instance side. It Must be send at the end of the authorization flow

200.description:
Ok

BINDING HTTP-POST, according to Section 4.3.3 of the JWT Secured Authorization Response Mode for OAuth 2.0 specification

EXAMPLE JWT included inside the 'response' parameter of the HTML form that contains the authorization code generated by the authorization server (claim 'code'), the 'state' and 'iss' parameters.

302.description:
Found

No content

BINDING HTTP-REDIRECT

=>EXAMPLE Location Header: 'https%3A%2F%2Fwallet-rp.ipzs.it%2Flogin'

=>EXAMPLE Location Header: 'https://start.wallet.example.org?code=091535f699ea575c7937fa5f0f454aee&state=43bd14c0-79e4-4c1e-851d-109d07198e37&iss=https%3A%2F%2Fwallet-rp.ipzs.it'

Location.description: Contains the URL of the RP login service to redirect the web view of the Wallet Instance to OR contains code, state and iss parameters required for the token endopoint

Set-Cookie.description: Contains the unique application session identifier at the Wallet Instance side

post.summary: Issuing an access token to the Wallet Instance
post.description:
1. Wallet Instance have previously:
    • generated a public/private key pair for use with DPoP;
    • created a DPoP proof JWT for the /token endpoint of the Authorizatiuon Server of EAA Provider adding the DPoP public key in the JWT header and signed the JWT with the DPoP private key, according to Section 4.2 of the DPoP specification (RFC 9449).
  2. Wallet Instance sends a Token Request, that includes the WTE with its proof of possession (WTE-PoP) and the authorization code, to the /token endpoint of the Authorization Server for issuing an Access Token bounded to the public key of the DPoP proof presented in the DPoP HTTP header of the Token Request;
  3. Authorization Server validates the Token Request and the DPoP proof JWT in the DPoP HTTP header according to Section 4.3 of the DPoP specifications (RFC 9449);
  4. Authorization Server extracts WTE from the Token Request and control is equal to the WTE received previously within the PAR Request;
  5. Authorization Server generates an Access Token bounded to the public key of the DPoP proof JWT presented in the DPoP HTTP header of the Token Request (according to the EUDI IT Wallet specification) that represents the client authorization to access to the /credential endpoint of the Credential Issuer for issuing an EAA Credential; this Access Token presents a claim sub that contains an identifier assigned to the authenticated user and a claim jkt contains the SHA256 base64-url encoded of the public key defined into the DPoP proof JWT;
  6. Authorization Server creates a string containg a nonce value to be used to create a proof of possession of private key material that the Wallet Instance must present to the /credential endpoint with the access token (this nonce can be used only once and has a limited lifetime);
  7. Authorization Server sends the Token Response containing the DPoP-bounded access token, the authorized verifiable credential types with the DPoP-bound Access Token, the nonce and the nonce expires time;
  8. Authorization Server stores the Token Request, the DPoP-bounded access token, the sub of the DPoP-bounded access token, the nonce, the nonce expires time and the Token Response in local databse with association to PAR Request previously received and identified through the parameter code specified in the request.

parameters.name: DPoP
parameters.description:
The DPoP proof JWT (in signed JWT format) presented in the request to the /token endpoint of the authorization server for issuing an access token bounded to the public key specified within the JWK header of the DPoP proof JWT. The issued DPoP-bounded access token represents the client's authorization to access to the /credential endpoint of the credential issuer for issuing a verifiable credential of type 'PersonIdentificationData'.

JSON Header schema

JSON Payload schema

EXAMPLE ON JWT.IO

post.summary: Issuing an EAA Credential to the Wallet Instance
post.description:
1. Wallet Instance have previously:
    • validated the Token Response received from the /token endpoint of the Authotization Server of EAA Provider;
    • validated the DPoP-bounded access token, the nonce and the nonce expires time extracted from the Token Response;
    • created a signed DPoP proof JWT for the /credential endpoint of the Credential Issuer of EAA Provider, according to Section 4.2 of the DPoP specification RFC 9449 (this JWT represents the proof of possession of the key material the DPop access token is bounded);
    • created a signed JWT proof for the /credential endpoint of the Credential Issuer of EAA Provider containg the nonce, according to the EUDI IT Wallet specification (this JWT represents the proof of possession of the key material the issued credential shall be bound to).
  2. Wallet Instance sends a Credential Request to the /credential endpoint of the Credential Issuer of EAA Provider for issuing a single specific tipology of EAA Credential bounded to the public key of the JWT proof presented in the request body with the type of EAA Credential (i.e. DisabilityCard) and the format 'vc+sd-jwt'; the Credential Request includes in the Authorization HTTP header the DPoP-bounded access token and contains in the DPoP HTTP header the DPoP proof JWT as proof of possession of the access token sign private key;
  3. Credential Issuer validates Credential Request received, verify the DPoP-bounded access token in the Authorization HTTP header and the DPoP proof JWT in the DPoP HTTP header according to Section 4.3 of the DPoP specifications (RFC 9449); it must also control that the public key of the DPoP proof JWT matches the public key that the access token is bound to (it provides additional assurance about the legitimacy of the Wallet Instance to present the access token);
  4. Credential Issuer extracts JWT proof from the Credential Request and checks its validity, then controls if the nonce inside the JWT proof is equal to the nonce sent previously to the Wallet Instance within the Token Response and verifies the nonce expiration;
  5. Credential Issuer retrieves digital credential data from the Authentic Source specifying user identifier, generates the EAA Credential requested bounded to the public key of the JWT proof, according to the EUDI IT Wallet specification and the SD-JWT-based Verifiable Credentials (SD-JWT VC) specification (i.e. type 'DisabilityCard' and format 'vc+sd-jw');
  6. Credential Issuer creates a string containg a nonce value to be used to create a new JWT proof (with a new key pair) for the /credential endpoint of the Credential Issuer when requesting a new EAA Credential with the same DPoP-bounded access token (the nonce can be used only once and has a limited lifetime);
  7. Credential Issuer sends the Credential Response containing the EAA Credential, the nonce and the nonce expires time;
  8. Credential Issuer stores the Credential Request, the nonce, the nonce expires time and the Credential Response in local databse with association to PAR Request previously received and identified through the sub of the Access Token specified in the request.

parameters.name: Authorization
parameters.description:
The DPoP-bound access token (in signed JWT format) presented in the request to the /credential endpoint of the credential issuer for issuing a verifiable credential (i.e. type 'DisabilityCard').

JSON Header schema

JSON Payload schema

EXAMPLE ON JWT.IO

parameters.name: DPoP
parameters.description:
The DPoP proof JWT (in signed JWT format) presented with the access token in the request to the /credential endpoint of the credential issuer as proof possession of the access token sign private key.

JSON Header schema

JSON Payload schema

EXAMPLE ON JWT.IO

200.description:
OK

The response is a JSON object that contains the verifiable credential (VC) requested into the claim 'credential' (DisabilityCard EXAMPLE ON JWT.IO)

VC Header is a JSON object with this JSON schema

VC Payload is a JSON object with this JSON schema

The verifiable credential (VC) is a digitally signed JWT carrying the information about a subject in clear text and containing SHA256 digests/thumbprints over the selectively disclosable claims with the Disclosures outside the document, the format is defined in draft-ietf-oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt-07 specification (SD-JWT).

The SD-JWT and the Disclosures are issued as a single concatenated string, with the tilde ~ serving as a separator.
The first block comprises the SD-JWT, while the remainder constitutes the Disclosures:

~ ~ ~ ...

SD-JWT=..

Disclosure is created as follow:

1) Create an array of 3 elements in this order: salt (base64url-encode minimum 128 bits of cryptographically secure pseudorandom data), claim name, claim value;

2) JSON-encode the array generated at the step 1, producing an UTF-8 string:
$ echo -n '["RhsyYXJcJdmA2ERNQBMbPQ","serialeCarta","00000002"]'
--> ["RhsyYXJcJdmA2ERNQBMbPQ","serialeCarta","00000002"]

3) base64url-encode the byte representation of the UTF-8 string produced at the step 2 (the result is the Disclosure)
$ echo -n '["RhsyYXJcJdmA2ERNQBMbPQ","serialeCarta","00000002"]' | openssl base64 -a -A | sed 's/+/-/g; s,/,_,g; s/=//g'
--> WyJSaHN5WVhKY0pkbUEyRVJOUUJNYlBRIiwic2VyaWFsZUNhcnRhIiwiMDAwMDAwMDIiXQ

In the example given here, within the claim _sd of the payload of the SD-JWT we found the base64url-encode of the SHA256 digest of the disclosure 'WyJSaHN5WVhKY0pkbUEyRVJOUUJNYlBRIiwic2VyaWFsZUNhcnRhIiwiMDAwMDAwMDIiXQ'
$ echo -n 'WyJSaHN5WVhKY0pkbUEyRVJOUUJNYlBRIiwic2VyaWFsZUNhcnRhIiwiMDAwMDAwMDIiXQ'| openssl sha256 -binary | openssl base64 -a -A | sed 's/+/-/g; s,/,_,g; s/=//g'
--> z-x4bpMauoQeHehQCsZdBR8bxb3BGrgtvXzx_j5jM4w

{
"_sd": [
"z-x4bpMauoQeHehQCsZdBR8bxb3BGrgtvXzx_j5jM4w",
"K4qEHQzdFs5s6k5dj6gJYIhBjAFvNUcsAfFdqrWH-Ts",
"yB37NgCRRhNDOYjdOVuqwWhedVwSap27-NI2KeUSUEg",
"esHKF0E5W5mDIQ58XQ4QPa5o425zrLGQ8s6rn43peG4",
"yHQncyIGF5L0WLlP5Hko0tTY6VMWZaOPSK1cEd5Dc2E",
"krgefld8Noj4kLOdVxV3IWKTTK9IqecdS7srEB35zOQ",
"sd3cX15Io3WIFFOXBJFA7388b22MX2joI7I7PiCe20"
],
"exp": 1883000000,
"iss": "https://issuer.example.org",
"sub": "NzbLsXh8uDCcd7noWXFZAfHkxZsRGC9Xs",
"status": {
"status_attestation": {
"credential_hash_alg": "sha-256"
}
},
"vct": "DisabilityCard",
"_sd_alg": "sha-256",
"cnf": {
"jwk": {
"kty": "EC",
"crv": "P-256",
"x": "TCAER19Zvu3OHF4j4W4vfSVoHIP1ILilDls7vCeGemc",
"y": "ZxjiWWbZMQGHVWKVQ4hbSIirsVfuecCE6t4jT9F2HZQ"
}
}
}

get.summary: Retrieve Entity Configuration of EAA Provider.
get.description:
1. Wallet Instance calls the ‚Äú/.well-know/openid-federation‚Äù OpenID Federation service of the EAA Provider (Federation Entity Configuration Request) to obtain its Entity Configuration;
  2. OpenID Federation Service retrieves its federation metadata from the local database;
  3. OpenID Federation Service creates a signed JWT containing the federation metadata (Entity Configuration);
  4. OpenID Federation Service creates and sends the Federation Entity Configuration Response containing the Entity Configuration.

schema.description: Metadata that an Entity publishes about itself (in signed JWT format), verifiable with a trusted third party (Superior Entity). It's called Entity Configuration. (View the JSON schema).

post.summary: The Issuer provides the Wallet Instance with a Status Attestation.
post.description:
1. Wallet Instance sends the Status Attestation Request via HTTP-POST;
  2. Credential Issuer checks validity of Status Attestation Request and stores it in local database;
  3. Credential Issuer extracts the credential pop;
  4. Credential Issuer retrieves from the database of the digital credential whose hash is specified within the credential_hash claim of the credential pop and the credential holder user identifier (idANPR or CF);
  5. Credential Issuer verifies the credential pop signature using the public key to which the digital credential is bound, i.e., the JWK key contained in the cnf claim of the credential (the claim kid of the credential pop header coincides with the base64url-encoded SHA-256 thumbprint of that key);
  6. Credential Issuer retrieves digital credential data from the Authentic Source specifying authenticated user identifier;
  7. Credential Issuer performs a formal validation of the response received from the Authentic Source: checks if the data received from the Authentic Source is still valid or has been revoked and checks if it is the same as the data present in the database (hashes of the data returned from the Authentic Source are generated and compared with the same data present locally in order to check for any updates on the same).
    Note. In the case of at least one data update, the digital credential must be revoked by the Credential Issuer of the EAA Provider and no Status Attestation must be issued for this credential;
  8. Credential Issuer issues the Status Attestation in JWT format and stores it in database by associating it with the digital credential, creates the Status Attestation Response that encapsulates the Status Attestation and stores it in database with linking to the SStatus Attestation Request saved in step 2;
  9. Credential Issuer sends the Status Attestation Response to the wallet Istance.

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The signature of credential_pop JWT is not valid

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The Digital Credential can not be found by the Issuer

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The Issuer encountered an internal problem.

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered

post.summary: A Wallet Instance request the revocation of a Digital Credential
post.description:
1. Wallet Instance sends the Revocation request via HTTP-POST that includes the credential pop inside which is the hash of the digital credential for which it acts as proof of possesion;
  2. Credential Issuer validates the Revocation request and stores it in database;
  3. Credential Issuer extracts the credential pop;
  4. Credential Issuer retrieves from the database of the digital credential whose hash is specified within the credential_hash claim of the credential pop;
  5. Credential Issuer verifies the credential pop signature using the public key to which the digital credential is bound, i.e., the JWK key contained in the cnf claim of the credential (the claim kid of the credential pop header coincides with the base64url-encoded SHA-256 thumbprint of that key);
  6. Credential Issuer revokes the digital credential retrieved in step 4 and updates the database;
  7. Credential Issuer return an HTTP Response with status code 204 No Content to the Wallet Istance.

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The issuer cannot fulfill the request because of invalid parameters

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The Digital Credential to be revoked can not be found by the Issuer.

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The Issuer encountered an internal problem.

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered

get.summary: Login request for starting a user authentication flow

parameters.name: idphint
parameters.description: URL, in URL-encoded format, where the Wallet Authorization request must be redirect

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: Contains the unique application session identifier at the Wallet Instance side

200.description:
Ok

BINDING HTTP-POST, according to Section 4.3.3 of the JWT Secured Authorization Response Mode for OAuth 2.0 specification

EXAMPLE JWT included inside the 'response' parameter of the HTML form that contains client_id, request_uri, client_id_scheme and request_uri_method parameters.

Location.description: The Location response header indicates the URL of RP Wallet service to redirect the Wallet Instance to. This URL present in query string client_id, request_uri (randomized, according to RFC 9101),client_id_scheme and the request_uri_method.

Set-Cookie.description: Contains the unique application session identifier at the Wallet Instance side

get.summary: provides the signed Request Object to the Wallet Instance

parameters.name: random_value
parameters.description: A random value revealed from login service of RP

200.description:
OK

JSON Header schema

JSON Payload schema

EXAMPLE ON JWT.IO

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The request_uri is malformed or does not point to a valid Request Object.

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered

post.summary: Forwarding authenticated user data to the /authorize endpoint of the EAA Provider

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: Trust cannot be established with the issuer

client_id.description: MUST be set to the base64url encoded SHA-256 thumbprint of the public key specified inside the claim 'jwt' (in JWT format) of the cnf parameter of the Wallet Attestation JWT

code_challenge.description: A challenge derived from the code PKCE verifier that is sent in the authorization request

code_challenge_method.description: A method that was used to calculate the challenge. It MUST be set to 'S256'

request.description:
Contains a signed JWT (the private key used to sign this JWT must match to the public one in the cnf parameter inside the Wallet Attestation).

JSON Header schema

JSON Payload schema

client_assertion.description: It MUST be set to a value containing the Wallet Attestation (in signed JWT format) and the Proof of Possession of the Wallet Attestation (in signed JWT format) separated with the ~ character

request_uri.description: The request URI corresponding to the authorization request posted. This URI MUST be a single-use reference to the respective authorization request. It MUST contain some part generated using a cryptographically strong pseudorandom algorithm. The value format MUST be urn:ietf:params:oauth:request_uri:<reference-value> with <reference-value> as the random part of the URI that references the respective authorization request data

expires_in.description: Integer, it represents the lifetime in seconds of the request URI

code.description: The authorization code returned in the Authorization Response

redirect_uri.description: It MUST be set as the Request Objectredirect_uri claim of the PAR Request

code_verifier.description: Verification code of the code_challenge of the PAR Request

client_assertion.description: It MUST be set to a value containing the Wallet Attestation JWT and the Proof of Possession, separated with the ~ character

access_token.description: The DPoP-bound Access Token, in signed JWT format, allows accessing the PID/(Q)EAA Credential Endpoint for obtaining Credentials specified in the PAR Request

token_type.description: Type of Access Token returned. It MUST be equal to 'DPoP'

expires_in.description: Expiry time of the Access Token in seconds

c_nonce.description: String containing a nonce value to be used to create a proof of possession of key material when requesting a Credential

c_nonce_expires_in.description: Integer, it represents the lifetime in seconds of the c_nonce

authorization_details.description: Array, used to identify authorizations grainted with the DPoP-bound Access Token

entity_configuration.description: Metadata that an Entity publishes about itself, verifiable with a trusted third party (Superior Entity). It's called Entity Configuration. (View the JSON schema).

AuthorizationDetails.description: Object containing the detailed description of a specific autorization. Credential being described in the credential_configurations_supported map in the Credential Issuer Metadata

type.description: The authorization details type. It MUST be set to 'openid_credential'

credential_configuration_id.description: The unique identifier of the authorized Credential

format.description: Format of the verifiable credential type to be issued. This MUST be 'vc+sd-jwt' (selective disclosure JWT format)

type.description: Array of one string, used to identify the verifiable credential type requested

CredentialRequest_credential_definition.description: JSON object containing the verifiable credential type requested

proof_type.description: String denoting the proof type. It MUST be 'jwt'

jwt.description: The JWT used as proof of possession EXAMPLE ON JWT.IO

CredentialRequest_proof.description: JSON object containing proof of possession of the key material the issued credential shall be bound to.

format.description: Format of the verifiable credential issued. This MUST be 'vc+sd-jwt'

credential.description:
The verifiable credential (VC) is a digitally signed JWT carrying the information about a subject in clear text and containing digests/thumbprints over the selectively disclosable claims with the Disclosures outside the document, using the format defined in draft-ietf-oauth-selective-disclosure-jwt-07 and draft-selective-disclosure-sd-jwt.
The SD-JWT and the Disclosures are issued as a single concatenated string, with the tilde ~ serving as a separator.
The first block comprises the SD-JWT, while the remainder constitutes the Disclosures.
~~~...~

SD-JWT=..

c_nonce.description: String containing a nonce value to be used to create a proof of possession of key material when requesting a further Credential

c_nonce_expires_in.description: Integer, it represents the lifetime in seconds of the c_nonce

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The proof field is not present or the provided key proof is invalid or not bound to a nonce provided by the Credential Issuer.

credential_pop.description:
A signed JWT as a cryptographic proof of possesion of the Digital Credential

JSON Header schema

JSON Payload schema

EXAMPLE ON JWT.IO

A signed JWT as a cryptographic proof of possesion of the Digital Credential

JSON Header schema

JSON Payload schema

EXAMPLE ON JWT.IO

status_attestation.description: The Issuer then returns the Status Attestation to the Wallet Instance as a signed JWT

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: The redirect_uri is not valid for the given client

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: If the request did not use the POST method, the authorization server responds with an HTTP 405 (Method Not Allowed) status code

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: If the request size was beyond the upper bound that the authorization server allows, the authorization server responds with an HTTP 413 (Payload Too Large) status code.

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
error_description.example: If the number of requests from a Wallet Instance during a particular time period exceeds the number the authorization server allows, the authorization server responds with an HTTP 429 (Too Many Requests) status code.

error_description.description: Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
Text in human-readable form providing further details to clarify the nature of the error encountered
